- http://logs.openstack.org/34061/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/25539 : SUCCESS in 39m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34061/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/33089 : SUCCESS in 19m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34061/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/25245 : SUCCESS in 40m 20s
- http://logs.openstack.org/34061/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/12220 : FAILURE in 20m 24s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-22 01:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is getting closer, but still not quite where it used to be. In this test, I have 2621 dispersion containers and 2621 dispersion objects. 262144 partitions and 3 replicas on both rings. All container copies are good. 11 object copies are missing.

Here's the good run from the commit just before 7548cb9c47bef4d5b7f3439bdaea8811ec929eeb:

    $ ./swift-dispersion-report-from-7548cb9c47bef4d5b7f3439bdaea8811ec929eeb^
    Queried 2622 containers for dispersion reporting, 4s, 0 retries
    100.00% of container copies found (7866 of 7866)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the container partition space
    Queried 2621 objects for dispersion reporting, 5s, 0 retries
    There were 11 partitions missing 1 copy.
    99.86% of object copies found (7852 of 7863)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the object partition space

Here's what master does right now (note the -11 copy thing):

    $ ./swift-dispersion-report-from-master-right-now
    Queried 2622 containers for dispersion reporting, 4s, 0 retries
    100.00% of container copies found (7866 of 7866)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the container partition space
    Queried 2621 objects for dispersion reporting, 14s, 0 retries
    There were 11 partitions missing -11 copy.
    99.86% of object copies found (7852 of 7863)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the object partition space

Here's what this patch set does (note it never emits the "missing 1 copy" line from the old good run):

    $ ./swift-dispersion-report-from-this-patch-set
    Queried 2622 containers for dispersion reporting, 4s, 0 retries
    100.00% of container copies found (23598 of 23598)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the container partition space
    Queried 2621 objects for dispersion reporting, 5s, 0 retries
    99.86% of object copies found (23556 of 23589)
    Sample represents 1.00% of the object partition space'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-22 01:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oh, and I just noticed the x of x numbers are really high now.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Man, I was happy just to get the percentages right. :/'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:43:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Update WebOb version dependency

Both Ceilometer and Nova require 1.2.3 or newer. Lock
it to <1.3 to be safe.

See bug #1092227 for details.

Change-Id: Iefb97291867505f7ab496789db2307aef009b640

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-24 22:25:15.000000000', 'message': "Added extra-spec key scoping to the 3PAR drivers

The Filter scheduler uses the extra-specs data to determine capabilities
and back-end, and it also enforces strict checking. As a result previous
method of setting all the 3PAR settings(cpg, snap_cpg, persona, provisioning)
on the 3PAR volume using extra-specs on a volume type will not work with the
default scheduler. The filter scheduler will look at these keys and fail to
schedule deployment of the volume because no suitable back-end reports those
capabilities.

This fix will allow the custom keys (ie: hp3par:cpg=TEST_CPG,
hp3par:provisioning=full,...) to be scoped, unfortunately this requires
additional checks in the common driver to parse the keys.

I'll update the 3PAR driver section of the OpenStack Block Storage Admin
Guide in a follow-up patch.
DocImpact
Fixes: bug 1194289

Change-Id: Id3fde3b3a185eedf2b8193fd0dc6324d904e8834
"}, {'created': '2013-06-25 16:17:04.000000000', 'message': "Added extra-spec key scoping to the 3PAR drivers

The Filter scheduler uses the extra-specs data to determine capabilities
and back-end, and it also enforces strict checking. As a result previous
method of setting all the 3PAR settings(cpg, snap_cpg, persona, provisioning)
on the 3PAR volume using extra-specs on a volume type will not work with the
default scheduler. The filter scheduler will look at these keys and fail to
schedule deployment of the volume because no suitable back-end reports those
capabilities.

This fix will allow the custom keys (ie: hp3par:cpg=TEST_CPG,
hp3par:provisioning=full,...) to be scoped, unfortunately this requires
additional checks in the common driver to parse the keys.

I'll update the 3PAR driver section of the OpenStack Block Storage Admin
Guide in a follow-up patch.
DocImpact
Fixes: bug 1194289

Change-Id: Id3fde3b3a185eedf2b8193fd0dc6324d904e8834
"}]
commit_message:
Added extra-spec key scoping to the 3PAR drivers

The Filter scheduler uses the extra-specs data to determine capabilities
and back-end, and it also enforces strict checking. As a result previous
method of setting all the 3PAR settings(cpg, snap_cpg, persona, provisioning)
on the 3PAR volume using extra-specs on a volume type will not work with the
default scheduler. The filter scheduler will look at these keys and fail to
schedule deployment of the volume because no suitable back-end reports those
capabilities.

This fix will allow the custom keys (ie: hp3par:cpg=TEST_CPG,
hp3par:provisioning=full,...) to be scoped, unfortunately this requires
additional checks in the common driver to parse the keys.

I'll update the 3PAR driver section of the OpenStack Block Storage Admin
Guide in a follow-up patch.
DocImpact
Fixes: bug 1194289

Change-Id: Id3fde3b3a185eedf2b8193fd0dc6324d904e8834

I understand the use case. But I am not sure if the proposed solution is workable.

We got rid of global roles because they were deem "confusing". And I don't see the proposed solution is any less confusing. User's effective roles are not showing be default. Supportability could be problematic.

Also, suppose they do show up in the role list for user, but they can't simply be removed with "DELETE /project/{project_id}/users/{user_id}/roles/{role_id}". They had to be removed at the domain level. Again, confusing. Not sure how UI's going to handle this either.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-05-23 14:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (4 inline comments)

See comments inline.

Gyee - to your general point, I'd make the following comment:

Today, in v3, we already have the issue of "effective" roles by virtue of groups.  If I list my role on a given project via the api, I only get my directly assigned roles.  However, when I get a token, it includes my effective roles (i.e. direct assignments plus and assignments "inherited" by virtue of the groups I am in).  

Hence, this extension provides an additional way in which role can be inherited.  Because of exactly the concerns you raise, I propose we provide an extension to listing apis to allow you to ask for your effective roles if you wish (so I can see what will end up in the token).  However, we maintain the current philosophy such that, by default, an api will return the directly assigned roles - which you can indeed DELETE via the appropriate api.'}, {'account_id': 994, 'date': '2013-05-28 18:13:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-05-30 17:11:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-06-19 21:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Question. When a domain administrator creates a new project, in which inherited roles already exist, how does the administrator stop the existing users who already have inherited roles on the other projects in the domain, from getting access to the new project? Dont the existing users automatically inherit these rights in the newly created project? If so, is that what you really want to happen?'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-19 22:10:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

So none of this affects roles that are directly assigned to a project...these are not somehow now applied to other projects.  This is simply the ability for a project to inherit additional roles from the parent domain, if such "to be inherited" roles have been assigned to the domain.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-19 23:09:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

David - one thing to remember is that when we are talking about roles being inherited, what we always mean is that a role-assignment is being inherited.  In keystone, every role-assignment is a 3-party deal (e.g. Role X, for User Y, on Domain Z).  So when such a role assignment is inherited to a project, it does not affect any existing role-assignments on that project....all that is happening is additionally User Y will get Role X on that Project.  Other Users that already have roles on that project don't suddenly get Role X."}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-20 06:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 06:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29781/18/check/gate-noop/2813 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-06-20 07:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

Yes I understand this. You misunderstood my original comment. I was not questioning users who are specifically assigned roles in a project. Rather I was questionning the fact that when a NEW project is created (so it does not have any specifically assigned user-roles at this time), users who previously had nothing to do with this project, automatically get roles on this project through the inheritance concpet. Is this what you really want? And without any apparent way of restricting this.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-20 07:36:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

David - Ok, sorry, if I misunderstood.  Yes, a new project would inherit any role assignments that were defined for inheritance to all projects in that domain.  That is, indeed, the requirement.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-20 15:07:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 15:08:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-06-20 23:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-06-21 04:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Do not merge

The abstraction here is not quite right.

Roles should not be inheritted from the parent domain.  They should come from group membership.  It is OK if the same group that puts the user into the role in the domain is used to grant them a role on all of the projects in the domain.

There should not be "effective" roles.  Much of this API can be reduced accordingly.'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-21 07:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 07:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29781/24/check/gate-noop/2837 : SUCCESS in 1s
'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-21 07:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-21 07:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Adam - so as you know, as well as role, there are two other parts of assignment within our current model -  we could call them the actor and the target (e.g. Give role X to Actor Y on Target Z).  I agree that the actor should also able to be a user or a group - that's true for this proposal.  The only debate is how do you specify Target when you want it to be more than one object.  There are differing opinions - you can do this by some arbitrary expression (e.g. "domain="pepsi*"&project="*") , or some other logical construct that might exist (e.g. all projects in a domain).  I happen to believe the the later will be a very common requirement, and is probably a subset of some larger way of defining this.  As was discussed at length in the bp etherpad (https://etherpad.openstack.org/keystone-role-inheritance), we agreed that the best way was to create a structure that allowed the scoping of the target to be flexible and we could expand on it in the future, including the scope just being a single target (which is what all that is supported in the core version of this api).  Further, we agreed that we would make the addition of inheritance as a scoping concept an extension so that we are not committing oursleves to this if it turns out that we want to come up with some more complex and all-encompasing way of defining multiple targets in IceHouse.  Given that this is an extension, I am keen to see what else needs to be done to get this approved :-)'}, {'account_id': 6534, 'date': '2013-06-21 11:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

"The only debate is how do you specify Target when you want it to be more than one object."
Maybe you dont need to. Conceptually you are doing two things in the current role assignment, viz:
i) defining a new role (role A on project A is different to role A on project B)
ii) assigning the user to this new role

What is wrong with performing two role assignments, rather than having one complex expression i.e. instead of saying assign user1 to role A on projects A and B, then say
assign user1 to role A on project A followed by
assign user1 to role A on project B'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-06-21 14:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

What David is saying is correct.  It is not that you want to inherit the roels from domain.  There will be roles at the Project level that make no sense at the domain level.  Projects own virtual macines, networks, etc. directly, but   Domains never do, and the roles that map to managing them are not going to apply at the domain level, only at the project level.

If you implement this blueprint, you are going to end up with the role "network manager" at the domain level, which will make no sense.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-06-21 14:56:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: No score

I've been through the etherpad a few times, and obviously there are significant differing opinions on this one.  I won't block it moving forward, but I think we are adding too much complexity, and the wrong abstraction.  If the other core devs support it, it can move forward.

The problem is that we are thinking solely in terms of Keystone here.  The permissions are enforced by Policy, and the policy rules can be modified as well.  What you really want is inheritance of the permission, but since the only thing we control is Keystone, you are implementing here."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-06-21 21:27:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Think you have a typo there."}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-06-23 12:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-23 12:41:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 14:31:07.000000000', 'message': "Provide optional ability for roles to be inherited from domain to owned projects

Role assignments to a domain are already supported, in a similar way
to projects. However, in customer situations where administration of
role assigment is split between a cloud provider and individual domain
administrators, a cloud provider might want to be able to have roles
inherited from the domain (that they create) to the projects (that the
domain administrator creates).

To aid the listing or roles on a project, support is also provided to
optionally include all 'effective' roles, including those by virtue of
group membership and inherited from the domain.

bp/inherited-domain-roles

Change-Id: I8471b182337ae85600ac564795a2cc04fc85d1d5

role assigment is split between a cloud provider and individual domain
administrators, a cloud provider might want to be able to have roles
inherited from the domain (that they create) to the projects (that the
domain administrator creates).

To aid the listing of roles on a project, support is also provided to
optionally include all 'effective' roles, including those by virtue of
group membership and inherited from the domain.

bp inherited-domain-roles

commit_message:
Allow project roles to be inherited from their parent domain

Role assignments to a domain are already supported, in a similar way
to projects. However, in customer situations where administration of
role assigment is split between a cloud provider and individual domain
administrators, a cloud provider might want to be able to have roles
inherited from the domain (that they create) to the projects (that the
domain administrator creates).

This functionality is being provided as an extension, ahead of a more
integrated solution for IceHouse.

bp inherited-domain-roles

Change-Id: I8471b182337ae85600ac564795a2cc04fc85d1d5
